choices.text: Scratch sign is positive in this condition
Topical Terbinafine is the first-line treatment
Wood's lamp examination shows coral red fluorescence
10% KOH mount shows Spaghetti & Meat ball appearance.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male had multiple small hypopigmented macules on the upper chest & back for the last 3 months. The macules were circular, arranged around follicles & many had coalesced to form large sheets. The surface showed fine scaling. He had similar lesions one year ago which subsided with treatment. Identify the INCORRECT statement about the given disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Wood's lamp examination shows coral red fluorescence.

 

Option C.

 

  • Diagnosis here is Pityriasis versicolor: CLUES are chest and trunk having hypopigmented macules with fine scaling around follicles which coalesced to form large sheets, with history of similar complaints in past .
  • Pityriasis Versicolor is a disease where recurrence is common even after complete treatment.
  • Aetiology: Malassezia globosa > M. furfur, M.sympodialis.
  • Since it’s a lipophilic fungus it colonizes seborrheic and perifollicular areas.
  • Clinical features: Asymptomatic Hypopigmented (due to Azelaic acid) , sometimes Hyperpigmented (due to abnormally large melanosomes)

 

Hypopigmented variant of Pityriasis Versicolor is seen in the image below.

 

 

PITYRIASIS VERSICOLOR IS NOT A DERMATOPHYTIC INFECTION.

 

  • Investigation: Woods lamp examination → Yellow fluorescence.
  • The image below shows the pale-yellow fluorescence of Tinea versicolor under Wood's lamp.

 

 

  • Wood's lamp examination shows coral red fluorescence in erythrasma.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Besnier's sign (coup d'ongle sign or scratch sign or stroke of the nail):

 

  • When the fine scales are not visible, an important diagnostic clue may be the loosening of barely perceptible scales with a fingernail, which is called the scratch sign.
  • The most commonly affected site is the upper trunk.

 

Option B. Terbinafine 1% cream twice daily for 2-3 weeks

 

Second-line treatment: Oral itraconazole, 200 mg daily for 5 days

 

Option D. Potassium hydroxide (KOH) mount shows Spaghetti & Meat ball appearance.

 

 

First-line treatment:

 

  • ﻿﻿Topical azoles twice daily for 2-3 weeks

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The correct diagnosis of Tinea Versicolor involves recognizing the clinical presentation of hypopigmented macules with fine scaling and the typical KOH mount appearance.
  • Wood's lamp examination may aid in diagnosis but does not typically show coral red fluorescence in Tinea Versicolor.
  • Treatment involves antifungals that target the yeast Malassezia, with topical azoles being first line, rather than Terbinafine.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition Chapter 32, Page no’s 32.11-32.13

choices.text: They infect & survive in Stratum corneum
Aspergillus is associated with tinea cruris
Microsporum infects only hair and skin
Annular lesions are seen in these infections

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about Dermatophytic infections EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Aspergillus is associated with tinea cruris

 

Option B.

 

  • Annular lesions are ring shaped with central clearing i.e., only the edges are active & appear raised, or in different colour. Option D.
  • It is present in granuloma annulare and tinea corporis (Dermatophytic infection).

 

 

 

 

 

Dermatophytes include 3 genera:

 

  1. ﻿﻿﻿Trichophyton species infect skin, hair and nails. e.g., T. rubrum, T. mentagrophytes, T. tonsurans, T. schoenleinii, T. violaceum, etc.
  2. ﻿﻿﻿Microsporum contains M. gypseum, M. canis, and M. nanum. These infect only hair and skin (not nails). Option C.
  3. ﻿﻿﻿Floccosum is the only species in the genus Epidermophyton, it infects only skin and nails (not hair).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Dermatophytes infect and survive only in the dead keratin layers of skin (stratum corneum), hair and nails as they are Keratinophilic.

 

 

Option B. Aspergillus species are not dermatophytes & are not associated with tinea infections.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Dermatophytic infections are caused by a group of fungi that infect keratinized tissues such as the stratum corneum, hair, and nails.
  • These infections are characterized by annular lesions and do not include infections by Aspergillus species.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Page no 4.11, 4.13, 32.20

Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology 9th edition Page no 599

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presented with painful boggy swelling of scalp, multiple sinuses with purulent discharge, easily pluckable hair & enlarged lymph nodes in occipital region. which one of the following would be most helpful for initial diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. KOH Mount

 

Option C.

 

Tinea capitis variants:

 

 

  • Ectothrix (Spores & fungus present outside the hair shaft)
  • Endothrix (Spores & fungi present inside the hair shaft)

 

 

 

Kerion:

 

  • Kerion presents in Children with boggy swelling, easily pluckable hair, with regional lymphadenopathy.
  • It is a severe inflammatory type of tinea capitis.
  • The most common causative organisms of kerion are Zoophilic dermatophytes, T. verrucosum and T. mentagrophytes.
  • In severe cases, there may be pus along with sinus formation.

 

 

Treatment: DOC overall and for Microsporum →Griseofulvin

DOC for Trichophyton → Terbinafine.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. While biopsy and culture

 

  • This can provide a definitive diagnosis, but they are not the most immediate or least invasive initial tests.
  • They are generally reserved for cases where initial less invasive testing is inconclusive or when the infection does not respond to typical treatments.

 

Option B. Bacterial culture: This would not be the most helpful initial diagnostic test given the presentation strongly suggests a fungal infection rather than a bacterial one.

 

Option D. Patch testing: It is used for diagnosing Allergic contact dermatitis, not infections, and would not be useful in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The correct initial diagnostic approach for a suspected fungal infection of the scalp is to perform a KOH mount.
  • This test is quick, cost-effective, and minimally invasive, and it can provide rapid evidence of fungal hyphae or spores, which is critical for the timely initiation of antifungal treatment.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition Chapter 32 Page no 32.39

questions.text: A farmer having trauma history in lower limb following which a cauliflower-like growth developed on that site. On HPE copper penny bodies are seen. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. chromoblastomycosis

 

Option A.

 

Chromoblastomycosis:

 

  • Caused by Fonsecaea, Cladophialophora species.
  • Clinical features : The lesions start as warty papules, slowly enlarge to form a cauliflower like hypertrophic plaque progressing to large Cauliflower like hyperkeratotic masses over months to years, surface often studded with black dots .
  • Histopathology: Foreign body granuloma & Sclerotic / Medlar / Copper penny  /Muriform bodies

 

Treatment: Itraconazole.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. While mycetoma can also present as a growth on the site of trauma, it is differentiated by the presence of draining sinuses with granules and does not typically show copper penny bodies on HPE.

 

 

Option C. Sporotrichosis

 

  • It is a subacute or chronic infection caused by the dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii, commonly presenting as nodular lesions along lymphatic channels.

 

 

  • It does not show copper penny bodies but rather asteroid bodies in tissue.

 

Option D. Phaeohyphomycosis

 

  • This describes a group of infections caused by dematiaceous (darkly pigmented) fungi.
  • While it can present with various clinical manifestations, copper penny bodies are not a characteristic finding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The identification of copper penny bodies on histopathology is indicative of Chromoblastomycosis, a fungal infection that leads to characteristic verrucous skin lesions.
  • This finding, along with the clinical history of a cauliflower-like growth following trauma in a farmer, solidifies the diagnosis and guides appropriate antifungal therapy.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition Chapter 32 Page no 32.76

questions.text: A Rose gardener presents with the following lesion after traumatic inoculation. Identify the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sporothrix schenckii

 

Option B.

 

  • Diagnosis from the given findings is Sporotrichosis/Rose Gardeners disease.

 

Few important points about Sporotrichosis:

 

  • Caused by Sporothrix schenckii
  • An acute or chronic fungal infection where, a linear distribution of nodules is seen Commonly in gardeners, florists due to high thorn prick possibility.

 

Clinically presents with Linear noduloulcerative lesions (Sporotrichoid) aligned along lymphatics, with Satellite lesions.

 

Important Organisms Transmitted in Linear / Sporotrichoid Pattern

 

 

The given images show the distribution of lesions along lymphatics.

 

 

 

Histopathology: Asteroid bodies are seen.

 

Treatment: Itraconazole / Terbinafine / Saturated solution of Potassium Iodide.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Mycobacterium scrofulaceum

 

  • It is a nontuberculous mycobacterium typically associated with cervical lymphadenitis in children, not the lesion seen here which is indicative of a subcutaneous infection following a puncture injury.

 

Option C. Madurella mycetomatis:

 

  • It is commonly associated with mycetoma, also known as "Madura foot," which is characterized by a chronic granulomatous infection of the skin and underlying tissues with multiple draining sinuses, not the pattern of spread along lymphatics as seen here.

 

Option D. Phialophora verrucosa

 

  • It is associated with chromoblastomycosis, which presents with verrucous skin lesions that are warty and can become disfiguring over time. The clinical presentation would not typically include the lymphatic spread pattern as with sporotrichosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The clinical presentation of sporotrichosis, typically involving a series of nodular lesions that follow the lymphatic drainage from a site of traumatic inoculation, often associated with gardening.
  • The diagnosis is confirmed by the presence of the fungus Sporothrix schenckii in culture or histopathology.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition

Chapter 32 Page no 32.71

questions.text: A farmer comes to skin OPD with a painful, swollen foot which has discharging sinuses & dark grains coming out of sinuses. Diagnosis of this case scenario would be?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Eumycetoma

 

Option B.

 

The diagnosis with the given case scenario would be Eumycetoma (Madura foot)

 

 

Clinical features: (GST)

 

  1. Grains,
  2. Sinuses,
  3. Tumefaction/sweling

 

The below image shows nodular lesions that have broken down to form draining sinuses with purulent discharge.

 

 

Treatment:

 

  1. Eumycetoma:
  • Antifungals (Itraconazole)
  1. Actinomycetoma:
  • Welsh regimen: Cotrimoxazole + Amikacin
  • Modified Welsh regimen: Cotrimoxazole + Amikacin + Rifampicin
     

Explanation:

 

Option A. Botryomycosis:

 

  • It is a chronic bacterial infection that typically presents with granulomatous lesions but is not known for producing dark grains as described.

 

Option C. Actinomycetoma:

 

  • It is caused by filamentous bacteria, not fungi, and typically produces lighter-colored grains in discharging sinuses.

 

Option D. Sporotrichosis:

 

  • It usually presents as a nodular lymphangitis, with lesions along the lymphatic channels rather than the presentation of a swollen foot with discharging sinuses and dark grains.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Eumycetoma is diagnosed by the presence of characteristic dark granules in discharges from sinuses on the affected area.
  • These grains are aggregates of the causative fungi, such as Madurella mycetomatis, and differentiate eumycetoma from actinomycetoma, which is caused by filamentous bacteria and typically presents with paler granules.
  • Treatment involves long-term antifungal therapy and sometimes surgery.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II - 9th Edition Chapter 32 Page no 32.75

choices.text: Corticosteroids are associated with Tinea incognito
Tinea pedis is caused by Trichophyton rubrum
Tinea cruris is also called as Dhobis itch
Tinea unguium infects Nail folds

questions.text: Identify the False statement about various types of Tinea infections?
questions.solution:
Ans. D: Tinea unguium infects nails folds

 

Option D.

 

Tinea unguium is a dermatophytic infection of the nail plate (NOT nail folds).

 

Image below shows DLSO variant of Onychomycosis involving the Nail plate.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Tinea incognito

 

  • It is an uncommon clinical lesion of tinea that is typically brought on by improper application of a topical corticosteroid to treat a fungal infection.
  • Steroids reduce inflammation without removing the fungus, which results in a smaller, less raised margin, lost scaling, and decreased inflammation. As a result, diagnosis becomes challenging.
  • Pharmacological treatment of fungal tinea infection depends on the extent of the disease.

 

Localized disease:

 

  • ﻿﻿Topical terbinafine twice daily for 2 weeks
  • ﻿﻿Topical azole once or twice daily for 2-4 weeks

 

Widespread disease:

 

  • ﻿﻿First-line - oral terbinafine 250 mg/day 2-3 weeks or oral itraconazole 100 mg/day 2-4 weeks
  • ﻿﻿Second line - oral griseofulvin 1 g/day for 4 weeks

 

Option B. Tinea pedis or ringworm of foot is most commonly caused by Trichophyton rubrum infections (70%) > Trichophyton interdigitale infections (15%), Epidermophyton floccosum infections (<10%), and mixed infections (5%).

 

 

Option C. A type of dermatophyte causes Dhobi's itch/tinea cruris, an infection of the groin. It is also referred to as eczema marginatum or groin ringworm.

The primary cause is T. rubrum, but T. interdigitale and E. floccosum are also responsible for some cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tinea unguium refers to a fungal infection of the nail plate itself, not the nail folds.
  • It's important to differentiate between the various tinea infections as they affect different parts of the body and may require different approaches to treatment.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Page no 32.38-32.50

questions.text: Which type of oral candidiasis does not present with a white patch?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Chronic atrophic candidiasis

 

Option A.

 

Chronic atrophic candidiasis presents with a red patch, (NOT white).

 

 

 

Various types of candidiasis:

 

  • Candidial intertrigo: Manifests with erythematous, non-scaly moist patches with tiny, superficial, white pustular satellite lesions seen at the margins of the patch.
  • Candidial paronychia: Swelling of nail fold
  • Candidial balanoposthitis: Seen in patients with uncontrolled diabetes mellitus, associated with swelling of prepuce.
  • Perlèche/ Angular stomatitis: Soreness and cracking at the angles of the mouth are seen in Perlèche. It is considered as an intertrigo where candida is the most common organism implicated.

 

 

Investigations:

 

  • KOH mount → Pseudo hyphae

 

Treatment: 

 

Topical: Antifungal clotrimazole is routinely used.

 

Oral: Fluconazole

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When diagnosing types of oral candidiasis, it is important to recognize that chronic atrophic candidiasis does not present with a white patch but is characterized by red, atrophic areas usually associated with dental prosthesis wear.
  • In contrast, other forms of oral candidiasis, such as pseudomembranous and hyperplastic types, are typically associated with white patches or plaques.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition Page nos 32.61-32.63

questions.text: A child was brought with complaints of hair loss in a patchy form over the scalp associated with easy pluckability of hair. Physical examination reveals black spots on the patch of hair loss as shown in the image below. Which of the following oral medications is used in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Griseofulvin

 

Option C.

 

  • It is the correct answer as it is an antifungal medication that is particularly effective against dermatophyte infections of the skin and hair, such as tinea capitis, which is likely the condition described.
  • The presence of black dots on the scalp, which are indicative of hair broken off at the follicle, is characteristic of a fungal infection of the hair known as "black dot" tinea capitis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Amphotericin B

 

  • It is an antifungal medication used to treat serious systemic fungal infections and is not typically used for fungal infections of the scalp.

 

Option B. Fluconazole

 

  • It is used to treat a variety of fungal infections, but it is not the first-line treatment for tinea capitis.
  • Fluconazole can be used when griseofulvin is not tolerated or ineffective.

 

Option D. Ivermectin:

 

  • It is an antiparasitic medication used for conditions such as scabies and some worm infestations, not fungal infections.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Griseofulvin is the oral medication of choice for the treatment of tinea capitis, a dermatophyte infection of the scalp that presents with patchy hair loss and black dot appearance due to broken hair shafts at the scalp surface.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 32.40

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1339

questions.text: A young man presents with the following skin lesions as shown in the image below. Which of the following organisms can least likely spread through dermal and subcutaneous lymphatics?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Staphylococcus aureus

 

Option B.

 

Given image depicts ulcerating nodules in a linear pattern suggesting Nodular lymphangitis.

 

Staphylococcus aureus

 

  • It typically causes localized or systemic infections through direct invasion rather than spreading via dermal and subcutaneous lymphatics.
  • While it can cause lymphatic involvement in the form of lymphangitis, it is more commonly associated with abscesses or cellulitis.
  • So, among the given options, this is the least likely organism to manifest along lymphatics.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Mycobacterium marinum: It can cause a chronic condition known as "aquarium granuloma" or "fish tank granuloma," which can spread along the lymphatics.

 

Option C. Nocardia: It can cause cutaneous nocardiosis, which may manifest as lymphocutaneous disease, with spread along lymphatic channels.

 

Option D. Sporothrix schenckii: It is the causative agent of sporotrichosis, which classically spreads via lymphatics, leading to a nodular lymphangitis.

 

Important Organisms Transmitted in Linear / Sporotrichoid Pattern

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Staphylococcus aureus typically does not spread through the dermal and subcutaneous lymphatics as commonly as the other organisms listed, which are known for this pattern of dissemination.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 105.51

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 9

questions.text: A forest worker developed skin lesions over the forearm. Histology of the nodules shows the following findings. Which are the following is true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Organism does not invade underlying fascia, tendons, and muscles.

 

Option B.

 

Correct as chromoblastomycosis typically involves the skin and subcutaneous tissue without deeper tissue invasion.

 

The bodies seen in the image are sclerotic or copper penny bodies typical of chromoblastomycosis.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Incorrect because the bodies seen in the image are sclerotic or copper penny bodies typical of chromoblastomycosis, which are not formed by engulfment of fungi by macrophages but are actually the characteristic form of the fungus in the tissue.


Differential Diagnosis of Parasitized Macrophages:

 

 

Option C. Incorrect because the organism causing chromoblastomycosis is not dimorphic and the yeast forms mentioned are not associated with this disease.

 

Dimorphic Fungi and Associated Diseases

 

 

Option D. Incorrect. Angioinvasion is not a common feature of chromoblastomycosis; it is more associated with other invasive fungal infections in immunocompromised patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chromoblastomycosis, is a chronic fungal infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue caused by dematiaceous fungi, characterized by sclerotic bodies seen on histology and typically NOT invading deeper structures like fascia, tendons, and muscles.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 32.76

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1347, 1353

questions.text: A forest worker has a cauliflower like lesion on the foot as shown in the image below. The histopathology from the lesion is given below. What is the most likely finding shown in the histopathology?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Copper penny bodies

 

Option A.

 

Given the provided description and the histopathological image, it appears that the correct answer is A. Copper penny bodies.

 

Copper penny bodies:

 

  • These are typically associated with chromoblastomycosis, a chronic fungal skin infection that often presents as cauliflower-like lesions on the extremities of people who work in forestry or agriculture.
  • The histopathology would show sclerotic cells or Medlar bodies, which can appear brown on H&E staining and resemble a copper penny.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Splendore Hoeppli phenomenon / Asteroid bodies:

 

  • This phenomenon is characterized by intensely eosinophilic material (antigen-antibody complexes) that radiates out from a bacteria, parasites and fungal organisms, creating a starry appearance.

 

 

Conditions Associated with Splendore Hoeppli Phenomenon

 

 

  • This is not typically seen in chromoblastomycosis.

 

Option C. Encapsulated budding yeast:

 

  • This description fits the histopathology of cryptococcosis more than chromoblastomycosis.
  • Cryptococcus is encapsulated and can show a clear halo around the yeast cells in tissue samples.

 

Option D. Macrophage ingesting fungi:

 

  • While macrophage activity is present in fungal infections, the characteristic feature of chromoblastomycosis is the presence of copper penny bodies, not necessarily the ingestion of fungi by macrophages.
  • Differential Diagnosis of Parasitized Macrophages

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct identification of copper penny bodies in a histopathological sample is indicative of chromoblastomycosis, which is consistent with the clinical presentation of cauliflower-like lesions in a forest worker.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 32.76

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1347, 1353

questions.text: A farmer presents with a swollen foot and multiple sinuses as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Mycetoma

 

Option A.

 

  • Clinical image depicts swollen foot and multiple sinuses, which in the context of farmer, is consistent with a diagnosis of Mycetoma.

 

Mycetoma:

 

  • It is a chronic granulomatous infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissues, which can extend to the underlying bone.
  • It typically presents in farmers or individuals who walk barefoot in endemic areas, with swollen feet and multiple sinuses that may discharge grains.

 

 

Option B. A Rodent ulcer

 

  • It is more commonly known as a basal cell carcinoma, typically presents as a skin lesion that may ulcerate but does not produce sinus tracts and granules.

 

Option C. Sporotrichosis

 

  • This is a fungal infection that typically presents as nodular lesions along lymphatic drainage, not typically with multiple sinuses and granules.

 

Option D. Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC)

 

  • This may present as a non-healing ulcer or nodule in sun-exposed areas but would not typically present with multiple draining sinuses and granules.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The correct diagnosis of mycetoma is based on the presentation of a swollen foot with multiple sinuses and granules, often associated with an occupational history of exposure to soil.
  • Recognizing this presentation is important for the management and initiation of appropriate antimicrobial therapy.Top of FormBottom of Form

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 32.73

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1350

questions.text: A child presents with complaints of itching over scalp. On examination a patch of hair loss, with redness is noted as shown in the image below. Which of the following investigations would help to diagnose the most probable diagnosis in this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Potassium hydroxide mount (KOH)

 

Option D.

 

It is a simple and quick test that helps to diagnose fungal infections of the skin, nails and hair, which are a common cause of itchy scalp and hair loss in children.

 

Tinea capitis:

 

  • If a child presents with complaints of hair loss and itching, the most likely diagnosis based on these clinical findings is tinea capitis.
  • KOH is the test useful to confirm the diagnosis in this case scenario.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Scalp biopsy: It is a more invasive test that's used for complex cases where the diagnosis is not clear. It's not usually the first step.

 

Option B. Gram stain: It is used to identify bacterial infections, which are less likely the cause of itchy, red bald patches.

 

Option C. Slit skin smears are used for certain skin infections, like leprosy, which do not typically present as an itchy, red bald patch on the scalp.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For a child with an itchy scalp and a patch of hair loss, a KOH mount of the scalp can help diagnose a fungal infection, often the most likely cause.
  • This test is simple, quick, and a good first step in such cases.

 

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 32.39

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1339

choices.text: Caused by both Bacteria and fungi
Hematogenous spread is the most common mode of systemic involvement
Involves only superficial tissue and spares deep tissues
Splendore Hoeppli phenomenon is characteristic of this condition

questions.text: A 38-year-old farmer presents with swelling of the foot, multiple sinuses discharge over foot. Microscopy of the granule is shown below. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Caused by both Bacteria and fungi

 

Option A.

 

  • The condition, most likely mycetoma, is an infectious disease that can be caused by a diverse group of organisms, including both bacteria (which leads to Actinomycetoma) and fungi (which leads to eumycetoma).
  • The presence of granules in discharge is a hallmark of this condition.

 

 

Image shows histology of a grain, which represents tightly packed colonies of fungal organisms, which is suggestive of a diagnosis of Mycetoma.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Hematogenous spread.

 

  • This is not the typical mode of systemic involvement for mycetoma.
  • The infection typically spreads locally through direct extension from the site of inoculation.

 

Option C. Mycetoma involves both superficial and deep tissues, often extending to the muscle and bone, and is not confined to superficial layers of the skin.

 

Option D. While the Splendore Hoeppli phenomenon can be seen in mycetoma, it is not exclusive to it and is also characteristic of other infections. It refers to the presence of bright eosinophilic material surrounding microorganisms or parasites, seen in various inflammatory conditions.

 

Splendore Hoeppli phenomenon / Asteroid bodies:

 

  • This phenomenon is characterized by intensely eosinophilic material (antigen-antibody complexes) that radiates out from a bacteria, parasites and fungal organisms, creating a starry appearance.

 

 

Conditions Associated with Splendore Hoeppli Phenomenon

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mycetoma is a chronic, progressive infection that can be caused by both bacteria and fungi.
  • This condition is characterized by subcutaneous swelling with sinus tract formation and discharge containing granules.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 32.73

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1349

questions.text: A female patient presents with complaints of thick curdy white vaginal discharge as shown in the image below. Microscopy shows budding yeast cells with pseudohyphae. Which medium is used to differentiate the species of the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. CHROMagar

 

Option C.

 

It is specifically formulated to differentiate yeast species, including various Candida species, by producing distinct colored colonies for each species, which is essential for accurate identification and subsequent treatment decisions.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. LJ medium, or Löwenstein-Jensen medium, is primarily used for the culture of Mycobacterium species, not for differentiating yeast species.

 

Option B. Brain heart infusion agar is a broad-spectrum medium that supports the growth of a variety of organisms but does not offer species-level differentiation for yeasts.

 

Option D. SDA, or Sabouraud Dextrose Agar, is commonly used for cultivating fungi due to its low pH. While it promotes fungal growth, it lacks the differentiation capabilities found in CHROMagar.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Employ CHROMagar for the differentiation of yeast species in clinical samples, such as those from patients with candidiasis. This medium is particularly valuable because it provides a color-coded identification system that allows clinicians to quickly and accurately identify the causative agent and ensure appropriate antifungal therapy.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no

questions.text: What type of tinea is likely affecting the 10-year-old child who presents with patchy hair loss as shown in the image below, along with the presence of black dots in the areas of hair loss?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Endothrix

 

Option B.

 

  • The given clinical picture is suggestive of endothrix type of tinea capitis.
  • Tinea capitis is a dermatophyte infection primarily occurring in children.

 

Tinea capitis variants:

 

 

  • Ectothrix - Spores & fungus present outside the hair shaft.
  • Endothrix - Spores & fungi present inside the hair shaft.

 

 

 

Kerion:

 

  • Presents in Children with boggy swelling, easily pluckable hair, with regional lymphadenopathy.
  • It is a severe inflammatory type of tinea capitis.
  • The most common causative organisms of kerion are Zoophilic dermatophytes, T. verrucosum and T. mentagrophytes. In severe cases, there may be pus along with sinus formation.

 

 

Figure: depicting Boggy indurated scalp swelling.

 

  • Investigation: 10% KOH mount
  • Treatment: DOC overall and for Microsporum is Griseofulvin

 

Note: DOC for Trichophyton associated Tinea capitis - Terbinafine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of patchy hair loss with black dots in the areas of hair loss in a child is indicative of an endothrix type of tinea capitis, where the fungal spores are located inside the hair shaft, causing it to break at the scalp level.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition Chapter 32 Page no 32.8, 32.38-32.40

questions.text: A patient had a history of thorn prick while working in a rose garden and later observed linear spread proximally till his shoulder. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause for this clinical feature?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Lymphangitis

 

Option A

Lymphangitis commonly occurs when an infection spreads from a wound and enters the lymphatic vessels, causing inflammation along the course of the vessels. It is often characterized by red streaking on the skin, extending proximally from the site of the initial infection toward the nearest set of lymph nodes, and can be accompanied by systemic symptoms such as fever and malaise.

 

Explanation:

Option B (Blaschkitis): Blaschkitis, or lichen striatus, is an inflammatory skin condition that follows Blaschko's lines; it does not occur due to infections and does not present with linear red streaking from an infected wound.

Option C (Abscess): An abscess is a collection of pus that has built up within the tissue of the body and typically presents as a localized swelling, redness, and pain, not as linear red streaking.

Option D (Furuncle): A furuncle, or boil, is a deep folliculitis, infection of the hair follicle, that forms a pus-filled nodule. It does not cause red streaks along the lymphatic vessels.

 

Educational Objective:

Lymphangitis is characterized by red streaking on the skin, which represents inflammation of the lymphatic channels, usually occurring secondary to an infectious process spreading from a distal site of injury, such as a thorn prick.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition Chapter 32 Page no 32,71

questions.text: A drug used to treat Tinea cruris that is experiencing an increasing development of widespread resistance is?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Terbinafine

 

Option C.

 

  • Terbinafine is an antifungal used to treat Tinea cruris ("Jock/Dhobi itch").
  • Tinea cruris is typically caused by the fungus Trichophyton rubrum.
  • Effectiveness of terbinafine is compromised due to increasing resistance, especially in chronic or recurrent infections.
  • Resistance to terbinafine is associated with mutations in the squalene epoxidase gene, diminishing the drug’s efficacy.

 

 

 

  • Squalene epoxidase is vital for ergosterol synthesis, crucial for the fungal cell membrane.
  • Terbinafine-resistant fungal strains are cross-resistant to other squalene epoxidase inhibitors.

 

NOTE: Despite resistance to terbinafine, these strains remain sensitive to azoles and other antifungal classes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Itraconazole:

 

  • While Itraconazole is effective against dermatophytoses, , but there's no specific indication of increasing resistance against it in the context of Tinea cruris.
  • Mechanism of Action: Itraconazole inhibits the enzyme cytochrome P450 14α-demethylase, which is necessary for the conversion of lanosterol to ergosterol in the fungal cell membrane. This leads to accumulation of toxic intermediates and membrane dysfunction.

 

Option B. Griseofulvin:

 

  • This drug is used for treatment, but there's no specific indication of increasing resistance against it in the context of Tinea cruris.
  • Mechanism of Action: Griseofulvin binds to tubulin, disrupting the microtubule function and thereby inhibiting mitosis in fungal cells. It specifically targets dividing fungal cells.

 

Option D. Voriconazole:

 

  • Mechanism of Action: Similar to Itraconazole, Voriconazole also inhibits the cytochrome P450 enzyme involved in the production of ergosterol for the fungal cell membrane.
  • It has a broad spectrum of antifungal activity. But it is not routinely used for treating superficial fungal infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Terbinafine is increasingly encountering resistance in the treatment of Tinea cruris, likely due to mutations in the fungal enzyme squalene epoxidase, which is the drug's target.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis seen in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Candidal intertrigo

 

Option B.

 

The condition shown in the image is Candidal intertrigo.

 

Various types of candidiasis:

 

  1. Candidal intertrigo:

  • Manifests with erythematous, non-scaly moist patches of opposing skin surfaces, with a little moist exudation starting deep in a fold.

  • When the web spaces of the toes or fingers are affected, marked maceration with a thick, white, horny layer is usually prominent.

  • Tiny, superficial, white pustular satellite lesions can be seen at the margins of the intertriginous patch.

  1. Candidal paronychia: Swelling of nail fold

  2. Candidal balanoposthitis: Seen in patients with uncontrolled diabetes mellitus, associated with swelling of prepuce.

  3. Perlèche/ Angular stomatitis: Soreness and cracking at the angles of the mouth are seen in Perlèche. It is considered as an intertrigo where candida is the most common organism implicated.

 

 

Investigations:

 

  • KOH mount → Pseudo hyphae

 

 Treatment: 

 

  • Topical: Antifungal agents such as nystatin, ketoconazole, and clotrimazole are routinely used.

  • Oral: Fluconazole

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Candidal paronychia

 

  • This refers to an infection of the nail fold, leading to a painful and red swelling around the nail.

  • It can be due to bacterial or candidal infection.

 

Option C. Diabetic foot ulcer

 

  • This is an open sore or wound commonly located on the bottom of the foot in people with diabetes.

  • Factors leading to diabetic foot ulcers include neuropathy, peripheral arterial disease, foot deformities, and trauma.

  • The skin around the ulcer may be calloused or discolored but not typically macerated.

 

Option D. Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS)

 

  • This is a serious skin disorder caused by the exotoxins of Staphylococcus aureus.

  • It primarily affects infants and young children.

  • It is characterized by blistering and the appearance that the top layer of skin is scalded or burned.

  • SSSS affects larger areas of the body and often starts with facial erythema, widespread redness, and blisters, which then rupture, leaving raw areas. Maceration of toe web spaces would not be a primary symptom.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Candidal intertrigo can be identified by the classic presentation of erythema, maceration, and possible white exudate in skin folds, such as the web spaces between fingers, distinguishing it from conditions that affect the nail folds, feet, or involve widespread skin desquamation.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition Chapter 32, Page nos 32.61-32.63

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presented with lesions over the trunk as shown in the picture below. Which of the following treatment should be started in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Itraconazole 200 mg once daily for 1 week

 

Option B.

 

The clinical image shows multiple hypopigmented patches with fine branny powdery scaling over trunk, which is suggestive of Pityriasis versicolor traconazole

 

  • This is an effective treatment for Tinea Versicolor, a superficial skin infection caused by yeast, typically from the genus Malassezia. The usual dose is 200 mg once daily for one week.
  • This treatment is preferred due to its effectiveness and shorter duration of therapy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Griseofulvin: This is a treatment option for dermatophyte infections of the scalp and nails but is not the first-line treatment for the condition likely depicted in the image, which resembles Tinea Versicolor.

 

Option C. Ketoconazole is another antifungal used for Tinea Versicolor, but due to potential hepatotoxicity and drug interactions, it is often reserved for topical use rather than systemic treatment.

 

Option D. Terbinafine is effective against dermatophyte infections but is not the first-line treatment for Tinea Versicolor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The appropriate treatment for Tinea Versicolor, as indicated by the hypopigmented and hyperpigmented macules on the trunk, is a short course of an oral antifungal such as Itraconazole.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 32.13

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child complains of mild painful swelling over the scalp for 3 months as shown in the image below. He also has a pet dog at his home. What is the diagnosis of the given condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Kerion

 

Option C.

 

  • The case of a young boy coming into contact with a zoophilic organism and displaying symptoms of a boggy inflammatory mass, accompanied by thick crusting and matting of hair, indicates a possible diagnosis of kerion.
  • Kerion is an intense inflammatory form of tinea capitis, caused by dermatophytes that have an affinity for animals (pet dog clue).

 

Tinea capitis variants:

 

 

 

Kerion:

 

 

  • Lesion: Boggy indurated scalp swelling
  • Easily pluckable hair associated with regional lymphadenopathy
  • Most common causative organisms - T. verrucosum and T. mentagrophytes.
  • Investigation: 10% KOH mount

 

Treatment: DOC overall and for Microsporum → Griseofulvin

 

Note: DOC for Trichophyton → Terbinafine.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Furuncle:

 

  • Description: Also known as a boil, a furuncle is a deep folliculitis, an infection of the hair follicle.
  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis: Furuncles are typically more localized and painful and would not be described as "boggy." Also, they don’t have a direct association with having a pet dog.

 

Option B. Epidermoid cyst:

 

  • Description: These are benign cysts originating from the epidermis. They are filled with keratin and have a characteristic central punctum as seen in the image below.

 

 

  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis: Epidermoid cysts are typically non-painful unless infected. They do not usually present as boggy swellings and are not related to having a pet.

 

Option D. Folliculitis:

 

  • Description: Folliculitis is the inflammation or infection of one or more hair follicles.
  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis: Folliculitis on the scalp would typically present as multiple small, itchy, and red pustules. It wouldn't create a boggy swelling as described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

kerion is a boggy, tender scalp swelling associated with hair loss and potentially linked to animal exposure, indicative of a fungal infection rather than a bacterial cause like furuncle or folliculitis, or a benign lesion such as an epidermoid cyst.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Page no 26.22, 26.23-26.24, 32.38, 32.39, 32.40, 90.27, 108.11
